author: bridge-bot
content:
<jacekglen> I have compared the worst case scenarios found in your PR to the MOD cases with the worst times in our benchmarks. The results are pretty much the same (see attached files). 

But I am confused by some other numbers. Computational complexity of ECRECOVER is much higher than MOD, which is reflected in our results as well. But in your example ECRECOVER is 110 Mgas/s and MOD is 220 Mgas/s, quite the same order of magnitude. Can you share the program you used to benchmark ECRECOVER? I'd like to run it through our tests and compare (re @chfast: I've done some work for verify the old/new numbers. I created a benchmark for MOD instruction because I'm guessing MOD is one of the weakest points.

https://github.com/ethereum/execution-spec-tests/pull/1151

This is in essence a sequence of DUPx + MOD instructions. And all the arguments to the MOD are in the ranges ~256 mod 192-128 bits because this is the worst case in evmone/intx.

In evmone, where ECRECOVER runs at 110 Mgas/s:
- MOD benchmark gives 220 Mgas/s with old numbers,
- SMOD benchmark gives 200 Mgas/s with old numbers.

With new numbers we should get:
- MOD: 55 Mgas/s
- SMOD: 50 Mgas/s)

author: bridge-bot
content:
<chfast> If consistent that's great.

I don't have a program for ECRECOVER, I just run the underlying function. But we can definitely make a benchmark program... (re @jacekglen: I have compared the worst case scenarios found in your PR to the MOD cases with the worst times in our benchmarks. The results are pretty much the same (see attached files). 

But I am confused by some other numbers. Computational complexity of ECRECOVER is much higher than MOD, which is reflected in our results as well. But in your example ECRECOVER is 110 Mgas/s and MOD is 220 Mgas/s, quite the same order of magnitude. Can you share the program you used to benchmark ECRECOVER? I'd like to run it through our tests and compare)
